ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: WOW! This class opened my world to the wonders of Dante! I think this is an important class that should be a requirement of humanities/literature/english majors. I learned just how influential The Divine Comedy is/can be, the proof being the profound impact it had on me (a modern reader) centuries after it was written. Dante is really everywhere!
Close reading, writing, literary analysis, thorough knowledge of the Divine Comedy and medieval philosophy.
Read the Divine Comedy on a high level. Wrote in-depth analysis. Learned historical context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lectures were incredible, and the section was nice to dive into the parts of the text that most excited us on the first read. It's an impossible task to read the whole Divine Comedy in a semester, so at times it felt a little overwhelming with how fast we were covering it, but I think it speaks to this great teaching duo that they were able to present so much content to first time readers in such an inspiring way!

Strengths: Prof. Cuadrado's enthusiasm for and knowledge of the content, our thought-provoking discussions in discussion sections, comparatively low reading load, the Beinecke visit, interesting topic.

Weaknesses: Not a lot. The class is fast-paced, since we have to go through the entire Comedy in one semester, but that expectation is made clear at the start of the semester.

Strengths: Very easy to follow, lack of pressure, student experimentation for analysis is encouraged, passionate professor.

Weaknesses: Because of a student focus there is a lack of a strict structure that might put off certain people.

strengths: lectures
weaknesses: student participation could be greater in lectures

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES YES YES!! Go into it with an open mind and you will not be disappointed. These were some of the best professors I've had at Yale, and the content of Dante was way more accessible than I ever thought thanks to the design of this course. It's a foundational work that I believe every humanities student should study, and it was truly a delight to read it for the first time with the help of an amazing professor! Be wary, you have to be into it - show up and do the reading, and I promise you will be delighted by what you learn!

Yes, if they're interested in Dante, medieval literature, or just want to read something truly epic. This class is interesting and relatively low-stakes, so you can explore a really impactful literary work with ease. You don't need to know Italian or have a background in reading epic poetry -- Prof. Cuadrado will help you navigate the afterlife, just as Virgil does for Dante.

100%. In a heartbeat. This course allowed me to read a major work in the canon at a very digestible pace and at a level where I can understand even the latest findings. The environment was comfortable and encouraging, to the point where I felt comfortable making mistakes because those would lead to further understanding. The discussions were engaged and nuanced. Basically everything that literature class could be, this class was.
yes! everyone should read Dante and this course is amazing
